summary: This is a court order from Judge Loretta A. Preska denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion for reconsideration of an order to unseal 20 lines of her July 2016 deposition transcript. The order discusses the legal standard for reconsideration and rejects Maxwell's arguments regarding privacy, confidentiality, and potential prejudice to her criminal trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the civil case who filed a motion seeking to keep portions of her 2016 deposition transcript sealed. The court denies her motion for reconsideration.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge who authored the order denying Maxwell's motion for reconsideration of the unsealing order.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney who submitted the letter motion for reconsideration (dkt. no. 1191) and a reply (dkt. no. 1204) on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Julie Brown
persons.context: A non-party who, along with the Miami Herald Media Co., opposed Maxwell's motion to keep the deposition transcript sealed.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Attorney who submitted a letter dated January 27, 2021 (dkt. no. 1194) opposing Maxwell's motion.

persons.name: Christine N. Walz
persons.context: Attorney who submitted a letter dated January 27, 2021 (dkt. no. 1195) opposing Maxwell's motion.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is acting as legal counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, filing motions on her behalf.
Julie Brown, a journalist, is a non-party opposing Maxwell's motion to seal deposition testimony, indicating an adversarial relationship in the context of court transparency.
Sigrid McCawley filed an opposition to Maxwell's motion to seal, indicating she represents an opposing interest in the litigation.
Christine N. Walz filed an opposition to Maxwell's motion to seal, indicating she represents an opposing interest in the litigation.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in July 2016. A specific 20-line portion (page 112, line 17 to page 113, line 12) was the subject of a sealing and unsealing dispute.

events.title: Court Hearing on Unsealing
events.description: A court hearing was held regarding the unsealing of documents, including Maxwell's deposition. The transcript of this hearing is referenced (dkt. no. 1196).

events.title: Filing of Maxwell's Criminal Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a motion in her criminal case to suppress evidence and dismiss counts, referenced as docket number 1206-2.

events.title: Order Denying Reconsideration
events.description: Judge Loretta A. Preska issued the order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion for reconsideration of the order to unseal her deposition testimony.

keyFacts: The court ordered the unsealing of 20 lines from Ghislaine Maxwell's July 2016 deposition transcript (page 112, line 17 to page 113, line 12).

Maxwell argued for sealing based on the testimony relating to 'adult, consensual activity,' confidentiality assurances, and potential prejudice to her criminal trial, but the court rejected these arguments.
The court found the testimony in question did not relate to private sexual activity but 'only to massages,' minimizing Maxwell's privacy interest.
Journalist Julie Brown and the Miami Herald Media Co. opposed Maxwell's motion to seal, highlighting media and public interest in the case.
The document references a separate criminal proceeding against Maxwell, where she had filed a motion to suppress evidence and dismiss counts.
